items.title: Rupee plunges past 91 per dollar for first time

featured_image.name: India central bank's FX forward book swells for 2nd month ... - Reuters

items.description:
The Indian rupee plunged past 91 per dollar for the first time on Tuesday, marking the fourth consecutive session of record lows as foreign investor outflows and trade deal uncertainty intensified pressure on the currency[1][2][3][4][5].

At midday trading, the rupee touched 91.14 against the US dollar, down 36 paise from its previous close of 90.78[3][5][6][7]. The currency has depreciated approximately 1% over the past five trading sessions alone and fell from 90 to 91 in just 10 trading sessions[3][5][8][6].

items.title: States vow to defy Trump order on AI regulation

featured_image.name: DeSantis: Florida has ‘right’ to regulate AI rules despite Trump’s order

items.description:
Multiple states are vowing to continue regulating artificial intelligence despite President Donald Trump's executive order seeking to establish a single national standard, setting up a potential legal showdown between federal and state authorities over who controls oversight of the rapidly developing technology.

Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis said Monday that his state has the right to regulate AI regardless of Trump's December 11 order, which threatens legal action and withholds federal funding from states with laws the administration deems "onerous and excessive." Speaking at Florida Atlantic University, DeSantis said the order "does not" prevent states from creating their own AI guidelines[1][2].

"Even reading it very broadly, I think the stuff we're doing is going to be very consistent," DeSantis said[3]. "But irrespective, clearly, we have a right to do this."

items.title: Asian, US stocks fall as markets await key jobs report

featured_image.name: Stocks slide as investors on edge ahead of data, central bank meetings

items.description: Asian markets tumbled Tuesday while US stocks slipped the previous day as investors braced for crucial employment data that could shape the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions in the year ahead, with concerns mounting over stretched valuations in the artificial intelligence sector.

items.title: Ford ends F-150 Lightning after $19.5B loss

featured_image.name: Ford To Stop Making All Electric F-150 Truck, In Shift To Hybrids

items.description:
Ford Motor announced Monday it is discontinuing production of the all-electric F-150 Lightning pickup truck and taking a $19.5 billion charge as the Detroit automaker pivots away from large battery-electric vehicles toward hybrids and more affordable EVs[1][2][3].

The company, which has lost $13 billion on electric vehicles since 2023, will replace the Lightning with an extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) featuring a gasoline generator that provides an estimated 700-mile range[1][2][4]. Production of the current Lightning ended this year after just three-and-a-half years on the market[5][6].

items.title: Tiny autonomous robots solve 40-year robotics challenge

featured_image.name: Penn and Michigan Create World's Smallest Programmable ...

items.description:
Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania and University of Michigan have unveiled the world's smallest fully programmable, autonomous robots, according to studies published December 15 in Science Robotics and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences[1][2][3]. The microscopic swimming machines, measuring 200 by 300 by 50 micrometers—smaller than a grain of salt—can independently sense temperature, process information, and operate for months while costing just a penny each[4][1][5].

The robots represent what researchers describe as a solution to a 40-year challenge in robotics. "We've made autonomous robots 10,000 times smaller," said Marc Miskin, assistant professor in electrical and systems engineering at Penn and senior author of both papers[1][5]. "That opens up an entirely new scale for programmable robots."

items.title: ISIS ideology drove Bondi Beach attack, Australian PM says

featured_image.name: AUSTRALIA-ATTACK-BONDI

items.description:
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese confirmed on Tuesday that the father-son duo behind the Bondi Beach massacre that killed 15 people were motivated by Islamic State ideology, as investigators revealed the suspects traveled to the Philippines last month and possessed homemade explosives alongside ISIS flags[1][2][3][4][5].

The declaration came nearly 48 hours after Sajid Akram, 50, and his son Naveed Akram, 24, opened fire on a Hanukkah celebration at Sydney's iconic beach on Sunday evening. "It would appear that this was motivated by Islamic State ideology," Albanese told national broadcaster ABC on Tuesday morning[1][6][7]. Federal Police Commissioner Krissy Barrett officially classified the attack as "a terrorist attack inspired by Islamic State"[4][8][9].

items.title: Alps could lose 100 glaciers per year starting in 2033

featured_image.name: Record number of glaciers will disappear from Alps soon

items.description:
The European Alps could lose more than 100 glaciers annually starting as early as 2033, marking the highest rate of glacier disappearance ever recorded in the region, according to a study published Monday in Nature Climate Change[1][2][3][4].

The research, led by glaciologist Lander Van Tricht of ETH Zurich, analyzed more than 200,000 glaciers worldwide and introduces the concept of "peak glacier extinction"—the point when the annual loss of glaciers reaches its maximum[2][5][3]. For the Alps, this critical threshold arrives earlier than any other major glacier region, occurring between 2033 and 2041 depending on warming scenarios[3][4][6].

items.title: CoreWeave loses $33B as AI bubble fears grip investors

featured_image.name: Exclusive | CoreWeave's Staggering Fall From Market Grace ...

items.description:
CoreWeave shares plummeted approximately 8% to $72.36 on Monday, extending a brutal selloff that has erased more than $33 billion in market value since the AI data center provider reached its June peak[1][2]. The company, which went public at $40 per share in March, has now lost over 60% of its value from its all-time high of $187[1][3].

The decline comes as Wall Street grows increasingly skeptical about whether massive AI infrastructure investments can deliver promised returns. CoreWeave's troubles have intensified broader concerns about a potential AI bubble, with investors questioning the sustainability of capital-intensive business models that rely on aggressive debt financing[4][5][6].

items.title: US military kills eight in latest Pacific vessel strikes

featured_image.name: US military kills four in latest strike on boat in the Caribbean

items.description:
The US Southern Command conducted lethal strikes on three vessels in international waters in the eastern Pacific on Monday, killing eight people in the latest operation of a campaign that has claimed at least 95 lives since September[1][2][1].

The strikes, carried out by Joint Task Force Southern Spear under the direction of Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth, targeted vessels that intelligence officials said were transporting narcotics along known drug trafficking routes[1][3][1]. The attack comes three days after Admiral Alvin Holsey, who commanded US Southern Command and reportedly clashed with Hegseth over the legality of military operations in the region, formally retired and transferred command to his deputy[4][5][6].

items.title: Global stocks fall ahead of key economic data and central bank decisions

featured_image.name: Stocks slide as investors on edge ahead of data, central bank meetings

items.description:
Stocks across Asia and the United States declined Monday and Tuesday as investors adopted a defensive stance ahead of crucial economic reports and a wave of central bank policy decisions that could shape the trajectory for interest rates in 2026.

The S&P 500 slipped 0.16% to 6,816.34 on Monday, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.59% to 23,057.41, pressured by continued weakness in artificial intelligence stocks[1][2]. The Dow Jones Industrial Average eased 0.09% to 48,416.57[1][2]. Asian markets extended losses Tuesday, with Japan's Nikkei 225 down 1.27% and South Korea's Kospi falling 0.75%[3][4].

items.title: Seoul court to rule on Yoon obstruction charges Jan. 16

featured_image.name: Police detect signs of records of Yoon Suk Yeol's secure phone ...

items.description:
A Seoul court announced Tuesday it will deliver its verdict on ousted President Yoon Suk Yeol's obstruction and related charges on January 16, concluding a case separate from his ongoing insurrection trial over last year's failed martial law declaration[1][2][3][4][5].

The Seoul Central District Court's Criminal Division 35, led by Judge Baek Dae-hyun, said the ruling must come before a January 19 deadline mandated under special counsel law, which requires first-instance verdicts within six months of indictment[1][5]. Yoon was indicted on July 19 by the special counsel team investigating the December 2024 martial law crisis[5][6].

The announcement came as special counsel Cho Eun-seok concluded his six-month investigation Monday, presenting findings that Yoon had plotted martial law since at least October 2023 to eliminate political opponents and consolidate power[7][8][9]. Cho's team indicted 24 individuals total, including Yoon and five former cabinet members, on insurrection-related charges[10][7][8].

items.title: Broadcom shares tumble in worst slide since 2020

featured_image.name: Broadcom Follows Oracle in Letting Down AI-Focused Investors

items.description:
Broadcom shares extended their decline Monday, closing down 5.6% at $339.86 and marking the chip manufacturer's steepest three-day drop since March 2020[1][2][3]. The selloff wiped out more than $300 billion in market value—roughly equivalent to the entire valuation of rival Advanced Micro Devices—and allowed Meta Platforms to reclaim its position as the sixth-largest U.S. company by market capitalization[4][2].

The decline comes despite Broadcom reporting fiscal fourth-quarter results that exceeded Wall Street expectations. Revenue climbed 28% year-over-year to $18.02 billion, while adjusted earnings per share of $1.95 beat the consensus estimate of $1.86[5][6][7]. The company's artificial intelligence revenue surged 74% to $6.5 billion and is projected to double to $8.2 billion in the current quarter[5][8].

items.title: Russia open to Ukraine EU membership in peace deal, U.S. says

featured_image.name: GERMANY-US-UKRAINE-RUSSIA-CONFLICT-DIPLOMACY

items.description:
Russia has indicated willingness to accept Ukraine's membership in the European Union as part of a peace deal to end the war, U.S. officials said Monday following two days of intensive negotiations in Berlin[1][2][3][4][5]. The development comes as negotiators reached consensus on roughly 90 percent of issues in a 20-point peace plan, marking what officials called "substantial progress" toward ending the nearly four-year conflict[1][3][6].

U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, President Donald Trump's son-in-law, spent over eight hours in direct discussions with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders on December 14-15[7][3][6]. The talks produced an agreement on NATO Article 5-like security guarantees for Ukraine, which U.S. officials described as the "platinum standard" that would require Senate approval[7][2][8][9].

"We believe the Russians, in a final deal, will accept all these things which allow for a strong and free Ukraine. Russia, in a final deal, has indicated they were open to Ukraine joining the EU," a senior U.S. official said, speaking anonymously due to the sensitive nature of negotiations[2]. While Russia has previously stated it does not object to Ukraine's EU membership, U.S. officials characterized Moscow's current position as a notable concession within the broader peace framework[3][4][5].

items.title: Over half of peer reviewers now use AI tools in their work

featured_image.name: AI peer reviewers are fine with AI-fabricated papers - C&EN

items.description:
More than half of peer reviewers are now using artificial intelligence tools in their work, according to a new survey that has prompted calls for updated publishing policies to ensure responsible and transparent use of the technology in scientific publishing.

A whitepaper released Thursday by Frontiers, an open-access publisher based in Switzerland, found that 53% of reviewers have used AI during peer review, with nearly one-quarter reporting increased usage over the past year[1][2][3]. The findings, based on a survey of 1,645 active researchers worldwide conducted earlier this year, reveal that many scientists are using AI tools "in contrast with a lot of external recommendations of not uploading manuscripts to third-party tools," according to Elena Vicario, Frontiers' director of research integrity[4].

items.title: Interstellar comet makes closest approach to Earth Friday

featured_image.name: New images show an interstellar comet that will soon make its closest approach to Earth

items.description:
An interstellar comet discovered this summer will swing within 167 million miles of Earth on Friday, offering astronomers their best opportunity to study the rare visitor from beyond our solar system before it races back into the cosmos[1][2][3][4].

Comet 3I/Atlas, traveling at 130,000 miles per hour, represents only the third confirmed interstellar object to pass through our solar system[5][4][6]. The comet will reach its closest approach to Earth on December 19 at approximately 1.8 astronomical units—nearly twice the distance between Earth and the sun—posing no threat to our planet[4][7][8].

items.title: BlackRock, World Bank lead Ukraine rebuilding plan

featured_image.name: Ukraine Secures $7.9B World Bank Support for 2025 Recovery ...

items.description:
BlackRock and the World Bank are spearheading a large-scale financial and rebuilding plan for Ukraine as part of ongoing peace negotiations, U.S. officials announced Monday following two days of intensive meetings in Berlin with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and European leaders[1][2].

BlackRock CEO Larry Fink has assembled a team working pro bono alongside World Bank President Ajay Banga to develop a recovery framework addressing Ukraine's post-war economic viability, according to senior U.S. administration officials[1][2][3]. The discussions mark a critical juncture in efforts to end the nearly four-year conflict while ensuring Ukraine's long-term stability, with reconstruction costs estimated at $524 billion over the next decade[4][5][6].

items.title: Interstellar comet to pass Earth Friday amid debate over unusual features

featured_image.name: NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope Revisits Interstellar Comet

items.description:
As interstellar object 3I/ATLAS prepares for its closest approach to Earth on Friday, the cosmic visitor has ignited both public fascination and scientific scrutiny while displaying features that challenge conventional comet behavior.

The object will pass within approximately 167 million miles of Earth—nearly twice the sun's distance—posing no threat to the planet, according to NASA [1][2][3]. Yet its unusual characteristics, including a persistent "anti-tail" pointing toward the sun and a striking color transformation from red to green, have fueled debate about its nature and origins.

items.title: CIA nuclear device lost in Himalayas in 1965 remains missing

featured_image.name: How Did the C.I.A. Lose a Nuclear Device in the Himalayas ...

items.description:
A covert Cold War mission to spy on China ended in failure when American and Indian climbers abandoned a plutonium-powered surveillance device on one of the world's highest peaks in 1965. Six decades later, the nuclear generator remains buried somewhere in the Himalayan ice, according to a New York Times investigation published Sunday[1][2].

The device, containing nearly a third of the plutonium used in the Nagasaki atomic bomb, disappeared from Nanda Devi mountain and has never been recovered despite multiple search operations[1][3][2]. Its disappearance has sparked environmental fears and renewed calls from Indian officials for a recovery mission, as the device lies near glaciers that feed the Ganges River, a water source for hundreds of millions of people[1][4].

items.title: EPFL launches software to run AI models locally without cloud

featured_image.name: Do we really need big data centers for AI?

items.description:
Researchers at École Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne have released software that could disrupt the artificial intelligence industry's dependence on massive cloud data centers, offering organizations a way to deploy powerful AI models entirely on local machines while keeping sensitive data private.

The software, called Anyway Systems, was announced December 14 by EPFL's Distributed Computing Laboratory and has already been spun off into a startup[1][2][3]. The technology allows users to download open-source AI models and run them on networks of ordinary computers without sending any data to third-party cloud services—a capability that challenges the infrastructure model currently dominated by major technology companies.

items.title: US says 90% of Ukraine peace issues resolved after Berlin talks

featured_image.name: European leaders agree Ukraine security guarantees should include European-led peacekeeping force

items.description:
United States officials said Monday that approximately 90 percent of outstanding issues between Russia and Ukraine have been resolved following intensive negotiations in Berlin, marking what they described as a breakthrough toward ending the nearly four-year conflict.

The assessment came after two days of talks between Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Trump administration envoys Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner[1][2][3]. "We've moved considerably closer in narrowing the issues between the Ukrainians and the Russians," one US official told reporters[2][4]. However, the official acknowledged that territorial concessions remain the primary obstacle to a final agreement[1][5].
